name: Ugali
description: Thick maize flour porridge, a staple accompaniment often served with stews or grilled meat.
recipe: Measure water and maize flour into separate bowls.
Pour water into a heavy-bottomed pot and add salt.
Bring water to a boil over medium-high heat, watching carefully.
Reduce heat to medium and gradually sprinkle a portion of the flour into the boiling water.
Stir constantly with a wooden spoon to prevent lumps.
Cook for 2–3 minutes until a smooth, thin porridge forms.
Slowly add the remaining flour in small portions, stirring vigorously.
Lower heat to medium-low and stir for 5–7 minutes until thickened.
Check consistency: ugali should form a firm mass that pulls away from the pot’s sides.
Press ugali in the pot to shape it smoothly.
Let it rest on low heat for 1–2 minutes to firm up.
Wet a plate with water to prevent sticking.
Turn the pot upside down to unmold ugali into a dome shape.
Serve hot, cut or torn into portions, with stew or meat.

name: Nyama_Choma
description: Grilled meat, often goat or beef, served with kachumbari, a fresh tomato and onion salad.
recipe: Cut the meat into medium pieces for even cooking.
Mix oil, garlic, ginger, paprika, pepper, salt, cumin, and lemon juice for the marinade.
Rub the marinade over the meat, coating all pieces thoroughly.
Cover and marinate for 30 minutes at room temperature.
Light a charcoal barbecue and wait until the coals are white-hot.
Place meat pieces on the grill over medium-high heat, spacing them evenly.
Grill for 8–10 minutes per side, turning regularly with tongs.
Finely chop tomatoes, onion, and coriander for the kachumbari.
Mix kachumbari with lemon juice and a pinch of salt.
Check meat doneness, cooked to medium or as preferred.
Let the meat rest for 5 minutes to retain juices.
Serve hot with kachumbari and ugali or fries.

name: Injera_with_Doro_Wat
description: Fermented flatbread served with a spicy chicken stew.
recipe: Mix teff flour and water for injera, cover, and let ferment for 2–3 days.
Stir the batter daily until it becomes sour and bubbly.
Add salt to the batter and adjust with water for a thin consistency.
Heat a non-stick skillet, lightly oil, and pour batter in a spiral.
Cook injera for 2–3 minutes without flipping, until bubbles form.
Stack injeras under a cloth to keep them soft.
For doro wat, blend onions into a puree without water.
Heat niter kibbeh in a pot and cook onions for 10 minutes.
Add garlic, ginger, berbere, and tomato paste, cook for 5 minutes.
Add chicken and water, simmer for 30–40 minutes on low heat.
Add hard-boiled eggs, adjust salt, and simmer for 5 minutes.
Serve doro wat on injera with rolled injeras on the side.

name: Matoke
description: Cooked and mashed green plantains, often with meat or vegetables.
recipe: Peel green plantains by removing the skin with a knife.
Cut plantains into pieces and rinse in water to remove starch.
Heat oil in a pot over medium heat.
Sauté onions until translucent, about 5 minutes.
Add garlic and ginger, cook for 1 minute while stirring.
Add meat and brown for 5–7 minutes.
Add tomatoes, salt, and pepper, cook for 5 minutes.
Add plantains and stir to coat with sauce.
Pour in water and bring to a boil.
Reduce to low heat, cover, and simmer for 20–25 minutes.
Lightly mash plantains with a slotted spoon.
Adjust seasoning and serve hot.

name: Pilau
description: Spiced rice with meat, often served during celebrations.
recipe: Rinse basmati rice and soak for 20 minutes, then drain.
Heat oil in a pot over medium heat.
Sauté onions until golden, about 8–10 minutes.
Add garlic and ginger, cook for 1 minute while stirring.
Add cumin, coriander, turmeric, cloves, cardamom, and cinnamon.
Cook spices for 1 minute to release aromas.
Add meat and brown for 5–7 minutes.
Add tomatoes and cook for 5 minutes to form a thick sauce.
Add drained rice and stir to coat grains.
Pour in broth, add salt, and bring to a boil.
Reduce to low heat, cover, and simmer for 15–20 minutes.
Let rest off heat for 5 minutes before serving.

name: Pap_and_Chakalaka
description: Maize porridge served with a spicy vegetable relish.
recipe: Bring water to a boil with salt for the pap.
Sprinkle a portion of maize flour into the water while stirring.
Cook for 2–3 minutes to form a smooth porridge without lumps.
Gradually add remaining flour, stirring vigorously.
Reduce to low heat and cook for 15–20 minutes, stirring often.
Heat oil in a skillet for the chakalaka.
Sauté onion until translucent, about 5 minutes.
Add carrots and bell pepper, cook for 5–7 minutes.
Add tomatoes, curry, and paprika, cook for 5 minutes.
Add beans and simmer for 5 minutes.
Adjust salt for the chakalaka.
Serve hot pap with chakalaka on top.

name: Bunny_Chow
description: Hollowed-out bread filled with spicy curry.
recipe: Heat oil in a pot over medium heat.
Sauté onions until golden, about 8–10 minutes.
Add garlic and ginger, cook for 1 minute while stirring.
Add curry, turmeric, and cumin, cook for 1 minute.
Add meat and brown for 5–7 minutes.
Add tomatoes and cook for 5 minutes to form a thick sauce.
Pour in water, add salt, and simmer for 20–30 minutes.
Cut bread into portions and hollow out the center, reserving the bread crumbs.
Ensure curry is thick to avoid soaking the bread.
Fill each bread portion with hot curry.
Place reserved bread crumbs on top.
Serve immediately with a salad.

name: Sadza
description: Maize porridge similar to ugali, served with meat or vegetables.
recipe: Measure water and maize flour, reserving a small portion of flour.
Bring water to a boil with salt in a pot.
Sprinkle a portion of flour into boiling water while stirring.
Cook for 2–3 minutes to form a smooth porridge without lumps.
Add remaining flour in small portions, stirring continuously.
Reduce to low heat and cook for 15–20 minutes, stirring often.
Check consistency: sadza should pull away from the pot’s sides.
Press sadza to form a smooth mass.
Wet a plate and unmold sadza into a dome shape.
Brush with butter for added flavor.
Cut into portions to serve with stew.
Serve hot with meat or vegetables.

name: Seswaa
description: Beef or goat meat slow-cooked and shredded.
recipe: Cut meat into large pieces, keeping the bones.
Place meat in a pot with onions and salt.
Add water and bring to a boil over medium-high heat.
Reduce to low heat, cover, and simmer for 2–3 hours.
Check water level and add more if needed.
Remove meat and reserve the broth.
Remove bones and shred meat with forks.
Return shredded meat to the pot with some broth.
Adjust salt and pepper, simmer for 10 minutes.
Stir to achieve a moist consistency.
Serve hot with maize porridge.
Accompany with vegetables or sauce.

name: Boerewors
description: Spicy sausage grilled, often served at barbecues.
recipe: Check that boerewors is in a spiral or pieces.
Light a charcoal barbecue until coals are white-hot.
Lightly oil the grill to prevent sticking.
Place boerewors on the grill over medium heat.
Grill for 10–12 minutes, turning regularly.
Check doneness: sausage should be juicy, not pink.
Remove from grill and let rest for 3–5 minutes.
Cut into portions if needed.
Prepare pap to accompany.
Serve hot with mustard.
Accompany with salad or grilled vegetables.
Enjoy immediately for optimal flavor.

name: Ndolé
description: Cameroonian dish made with bitter leaves, peanut paste, and shrimp or meat.
recipe: Wash ndolé leaves to remove dust and impurities.
Boil leaves with a pinch of baking soda to reduce bitterness.
Drain leaves and rinse with cold water.
Cook meat or shrimp in a pot with a pinch of salt.
Dry-roast peanuts in a skillet over medium heat.
Grind peanuts to form a smooth paste.
Dilute peanut paste with hot water for a creamy consistency.
Heat palm oil in a pot and sauté onions.
Add chopped tomatoes and chili, cook until a sauce forms.
Add diluted peanut paste and stir.
Add boiled ndolé leaves and meat or shrimp.
Add bouillon cube and adjust salt.
Simmer on low heat for about 30 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Serve hot with plantains, rice, or cassava.
